ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SKILLS DEVELOPMENT FUND
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the Minister for Finance, for the year 1980, (a) how much was collected for the Skills Development Fund; (b) how many applications for grants from the Fund were received and how many

Column: 794

of them were successful; and (c) if he will give breakdown statistics of the number of successful applications in terms of (i) the amount awarded; and (ii) days/months taken from the submission of an application to the notification that the grant had been awarded.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, the total amount collected for the Skills Development Fund in 1980 was $76.1 million. During the year, 716 applications for grants from the Fund were received. 299 of these were successful.

Column: 795



    The total amount of grants awarded was $14.3 million. $10.3 million was awarded to the manufacturing sector, $1.4 million to the computer industry, $399,000 to the commercial sector, $491,000 to the transport, storage and communication sector, $93,000 to the finance, insurance and business services sector, and $2.1 million to the public sector and other training institutes.

    The average time taken for the processing and approval of an application was about three months. The time taken for an application to be processed depends on how complete is the information supplied.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, could the Hon. Minister for Finance inform this House how many applications are still outstanding, and what is the amount committed to these outstanding applications for the use of the Skills Development Fund?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I am afraid I do not have the answer to that question right now. I will furnish the answer to him if he really wishes to have this information. I believe that the Skills Development Fund publishes data of this kind from time to time, but I will be quite happy to send him whatever information he wants on this.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, I asked the supplementary question because I expressed concern yesterday over the collection of the Skills Development Fund. Just now the Hon. Minister for Finance has indicated to the House that a sum of $76 million has been contributed. This is indeed a very big sum. Could he assure the House that this Fund will be used for the development of skills?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I do not think there is any doubt about this. After all there is a Skills Development Act which has been passed by Parliament specially for this purpose, and I can give him the assurance that the Act will be implemented to the full.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (Alexandra): Sir, in view of the relatively small amount that has been paid out by the Fund and the number of applications that have been approved, does it imply that the Fund has been too rigid in its consideration of applications?

Column: 796



     Mr Hon Sui Sen: The answer to that is "No." I accept that the Fund has been a bit slow in getting started, as all new institutions must: but the applications are now accelerating and they are being dealt with more expeditiously. More staff have been taken. I am told the applications should be dealt with within two months in the very near future.

    There are other schemes for use of the monies, such as grants towards the subsidization of interest on capital investments for improvement of skills. This will, I think, make pretty good use of the monies that are remaining, and I hope that the Member will soon see that the disbursements from this Fund will be much more than the numbers that are given so far.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (River Valley): I understand that the Skills Development Fund has been used principally for the provision of training for lower level workers and so on. Can the Minister tell us whether the Fund can be used for middle and higher levels of managers in firms? In view of our plan to go into higher technology, I think the middle and higher levels of staff are very important, and so whether the Fund can be used for that purpose.

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, the Fund has already been used for those purposes. For example, in the case of applications for computer applications in firms, many of the people who are sent overseas for training are from the managerial or higher technical classes.

INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS DIVISION
(Conciliations)


    2. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (a) how many conciliation cases were referred jointly by management and union to the Industrial Relations Division of the Ministry of Labour in 1980; (b) how many of them had to be referred to the Industrial Arbitration Court; (c) if he will give breakdown statistics, in terms of man-days spent by the Ministry's conciliation officers, of (i) the cases

Column: 797

that were resolved; (ii) those that were unresolved: and (iii) those that are yet to be resolved; and (d) if he will give breakdown statistics, in terms of the time taken (in days/months) from the point when the case was referred to the Ministry to its successful conciliation, of the cases that were resolved.

     The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, last year a total of 484 new unionized cases were referred to the Labour Relations Division for conciliation. Added to the 142 cases that have been brought forward from 1979, there was a total of 626 cases. Of these, 476 were resolved by the Ministry, 30 referred to the Industrial Arbitration Court and the remaining 120 were carried forward this year.

    The time taken to conciliate disputes vary. It depends on the nature of the dispute. The average duration for the resolution of a dispute on proposals for a collective agreement is about three months, while a grievance dispute takes about a week. However, in terms of actual time spent, each case takes less than one man-day on the average.

     Mr Liew Kok Pun (Boon Teck): Sir, may I ask the Minister of State what steps is his Ministry taking to speed up the conciliation process?

     Mr Sia Kah Hui: Any dispute referred to the Ministry is attended to immediately. Very often the parties concerned are contacted on the telephone to attend meetings.

    Delays can be due to several factors, if there were any delays. The representatives of the union and of the management may not have a mandate to agree to counter-proposals during the meetings. Therefore, the meeting will have to be adjourned for them to consult their superiors. Sometimes also one party may resort to delaying tactics for their own purpose. It could be the union, or it could be the management. Both parties play a kind of game too. So the conciliation officer

Column: 798

very often has to step in and make sure that they play the game in a gentlemanly manner.

    As we all know, the union's industrial relations officer has also to service its many branches. Therefore, meetings arranged for conciliation will have to be arranged in such a way to fit into his schedule, and that is another cause for delay. But as far as the Ministry is concerned, we are very interested in settling the dispute even on the spot, if we can do it.

VOLUNTARY WELFARE ORGANIZATIONS


    4. Dr Tay Eng Soon asked the Acting Minister for Social Affairs (a) how many active voluntary welfare organizations there are in Singapore; (b) how much financial aid is being given by his Ministry to those organizations; (c) how many persons are receiving help directly from those organizations; and (d) how many persons are receiving help from his Ministry's welfare services.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng) (for the Acting Minister for Social Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are altogether 156 known voluntary organizations in Singapore, most of which are affiliated to the Singapore Council of Social Service which is the coordinating body for volun-

Column: 799

tary welfare activities. About 70 of them are actively providing welfare services to the needy in the form of residential care for the young and the aged, social work services and special education and vocational training for the disabled.

    In 1980, these organizations received a total of $191,183 by way of token subventions from the Government. In addition, the Government seconded 11 instructors from the Ministry of Social Affairs and Ill teachers from the Ministry of Education to these organizations.

    Based on available information, the total number of persons being helped by voluntary welfare organizations is around 18,730. The number of persons who received welfare assistance from my Ministry during the period April, 1980 to February, 1981 was 22,485.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, I would like to ask the Acting Minister for Social Affairs what more can be done by his Ministry in this very worthwhile work they are doing to support voluntary welfare organizations. I think all of us. in this House are happy to note that there are so many voluntary welfare organizations in Singapore helping those that are aged, the young or the disabled, and they give us the hope that some of us at least are not becoming crass materialists. So my question to the Minister is, what more can the Ministry of Social Affairs do to promote voluntary organizations and people to go into such organizations?

     Mr Chan Chee Seng: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I answer on behalf of my Ministry? The label "voluntary welfare organizations" indicates that these organizations have the financial capacity and management ability. They also have ample capability of looking after their own problems. If we come in and assist them, then that organization is no more a voluntary organization. However, we do help some organizations when they need us, but normally they do not come to us for help. In case there are organizations which need the help of the Ministry, the Ministry would be happy to look into their request.

OF SINGAPORE FOR THE FINANCIAL

YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1981 TO 31ST MARCH, 1982



    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [1st Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]


2.45 p.m.

     The Chairman: Main and Development Estimates of Singapore for the financial year 1st April, 1981 to 31st March, 1982, contained in Paper Cmd. 9 of 1981. For convenience, I shall take the totals for each head of expenditure in the Main Estimates and the Development Estimates as they appear in the last columns of the schedules of Estimated Expenditure under the Main Estimates and under the Development Estimates on pages 21 and 22 respectively, of Paper Cmd. 9 of 1981.

    I shall deal first with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement.

    Head H -

     Mr Goh Chee Wee (Boon Lay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head H be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead HA-04 of the Main Estimates.

Column: 801



    Sir, may I have your permission to speak also on my next amendment?

     The Chairman: Yes.

     Mr Goh Chee Wee: Sir, while the Government has made a commendable effort to economize on the use of manpower by cutting down 465 redundant posts, we see the creation of 18 posts for the Professionals Information and Placement Unit. There is also a provision of $1 million for this programme under the Development Estimates.

    First, I suppose this Professionals Information and Placement Unit, unlike the Ministry of Labour's Employment Service, is not for the registration and placement of unemployed engineers, accountants or retrenched Government doctors and lawyers who cannot find alternative employment. This is meant to attract overseas talent to come to work in Singapore. In view of the investment on hardware and the commitment on the recurrent cost, I hope the House can be provided with more information relating to the objectives, the targets and the modes of operation of this Unit.

    I would like to know, in particular, Sir, in what way would the Unit go about in identifying and attracting the professionals, how far and how wide are we going to cast our net, how many overseas talents we hope to attract through this Unit, and how effective our effort will be.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry and Minister for Health (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Sir, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply on his behalf.

    From experience, the Public Service Commission found that many overseas graduates and professionals who are keen to work in Singapore do not know where to apply for suitable jobs, how to go about

Column: 802

applying for Employment Pass and what the living conditions in Singapore are. The functions of the Professionals Information and Placement Service (PIPS) are to assist and to facilitate such graduates and professionals from overseas, both Singaporeans and foreigners, by advising them on job opportunities, accommodation, education for the children, immigration procedures and so on. To do this job, PIPS needs a computer to maintain records of such persons so that they can be referred to the appropriate employers, both public and private.

    Another function of PIPS is to identify the highly talented graduates and professionals from overseas with a view to attracting them to work in Singapore. This is done mainly through the Career Advisory Officers of overseas universities with the assistance of our embassies abroad. The target countries are the traditional English-speaking countries. As far as numbers are concerned, the more talented people we can attract to Singapore the better. There is, therefore, no upper limit on targets.

    The breakdown of the Development Estimates for this Unit is as follows: purchase and installation of a computer system, $750,000: cost of office renovation of PIPS, $232,000; cost of office equipment and furniture, $74,000.

     Mr Goh Chee Wee: Sir, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $16,487,960 for Head H ordered to stand part of the Main Estimates.

    The sum of $1,000,000 for Head H ordered to stand part of the Development Estimates.

    Head U -

     Mr Rohan bin Kamis (Telok Blangah): Sir, I beg to move,

Column: 803



    That the sum to be allocated for Head U be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead UE-03 of the Main Estimates.*


    *The same amendment also stood in the name of Dr Lau Teik Soon.


    Sir, in moving this amendment, I wish to seek clarification and to offer a suggestion.

    The People's Association (PA) has made a great deal of positive contribution to the promotion of mass participation in cultural, social, educational, youth and other community activities. The community centre is the focal point of many community activities in the constituency. It is said that no matter how wonderful the hardware is, without the "live-ware" or the people, the system will not be effective, let alone efficient. Therefore, no matter how efficient, dynamic and forward-looking the community centre Management Committee members are, without the executive arm, the community centre would not function at the most efficient level. This executive arm is made up of dedicated, unassuming and hardworking Organizing Secretaries or Assistant Organizing Secretaries who are the permanent staff employed by PA. They have to work at odd hours from
2.30 p.m. to 10.30 p.m. with virtually no holidays throughout the year. In addition, they may have to come during certain mornings to participate and assist in any community projects organized by the various committees attached to the community centre. Furthermore, for new generation community centres, in order to serve the residents better, these community centres are open on Sundays and public holidays from
9.30 a.m. to 10.30 p.m.

    It is, therefore, not uncommon to find that not many people want to work for PA in the community centres. Many community centres are shorthanded or could not find the right complement of staff to man them. In this light, would the Hon. Prime Minister in-form the House as to what steps are being taken to recruit and, more importantly, to retain these staff in the community centres? I understand that the remuneration for such important staff in the field is less than adequate.

Column: 804



    Sir, the very logo of PA signifies the blending of our four major races together to help promote cultural, social and recreational community activities. Language is a subject that touches the hearts of many people and is held especially dear by those who speak it. I realize that in many instances it may be expedient or practical or even economical for PA to produce publications in only two of our four official languages. Since language is such an important aspect of our cultural heritage and is held dear by many, if not all Singaporeans, would it not be better if PA endeavours to produce certain important publications, at least, in all our four official languages? Would it not be better also if some of the major functions organized by PA show this sensitivity by having more than just two official languages used?

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Sir, the People's Association was established in the early 1960s with the major function of providing activities to mould our citizenship, and over the years, they have been very successful in organizing social, recreational and educational activities. Today, however, there are other community organizations, particularly the Residents' Committees, which are involved in the same task of moulding good citizenship and of providing social, recreational and cultural activities. Over and above these community organizations, there is the Citizens' Consultative Committee which is not only responsible for providing for the well-being of the physical environment but also participates in the activities of the Management Committee of the community centre as well as those of the RCs.

    What I would like to ask the Hon. Prime Minister is whether or not there is today a confusion as to the area of responsibility between the three major community organizations, namely, the CCCs, the CCMCs and the RCs. Aside from confusion, I also fear that conflict may arise because of competition for financial resources and manpower. I would like the Hon. Prime Minister to clarify this.

Column: 805



    In the effort to provide facilities for the community centres, the Citizens' Consultative Committees of the various constituencies have played a major role. In fact, in some constituencies, the CCC members form the bulk of the Building Fund Committee. I would like to cite, for example, the case of my constituency where practically all the members of the Building Fund Committee come from the CCC. What I would like to raise with the Hon. Prime Minister is whether or not some recognition could be given to the other community organizations which have contributed in the way of providing or raising funds for the construction of the building.
3.00 p.m.

    Specifically, a problem has arisen over the question of whether the CCC sign should be constructed or located at a prominent spot in the community centre. Here, I would like to appeal to the People's Association to adopt a more accommodative approach, be less selfish and less petty and allow the CCC to construct their sign on the exterior wall of the building. The objective of the People's Association has always been to promote good citizenship and I think the People's Association should show an example by demonstrating its goodwill to other community organizations.

     The Senior Minister of State, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Lee Khoon Choy): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Telok Blangah was very correct in appreciating the difficulties of the working conditions of the People's Association staff. I am very happy to hear that a Member of Parliament has publicly appreciated this fact and that he has described our Organizing Secretaries as being dedicated, unassuming and working at odd hours. Of course, we have made proposals to the Ministry of Finance to raise the salary of our staff since 1978, we only hope that the officials concerned with the public purse, particularly those dealing with the People's Association, are as appreciative as the Member for Telok Blangah.

Column: 806



    As regards the printing of Anniversary souvenirs and banners, naturally we appreciate and understand the significance of our logo, i.e. giving equal treatment to all the four language streams. The Member for Telok Blangah has always been a very observant person, but on that day it seems that he saw only one banner. There were actually two banners outside the National Theatre, one in English and Chinese and the other in Malay and Tamil. Because of constraints of space, it was rather difficult to put up too many banners on the stage. If we were to put four languages in one banner, the lettering would be so small that it would not be significant. If we were to put up two banners, then they would block the film projection and other backdrops. The stage backdrop, however, was in two languages.

    As for the printing of the Anniversary souvenir, it was the practice in the past to print it in all the four official languages in one big book. It comes to you like a bomb! However, we found that that practice was not practicable and also not economically viable. In the case of the 20th Anniversary souvenir, the purpose was to print it for the benefit of community leaders, Management Committee members and volunteers. According to our records, most of them are bilingual. They can read English and Chinese. Even among the leaders in the Management Committees, there are Malays and Indians who are conversant with English. The question is whether it is wise and prudent for the People's Association just to go through the ritual of printing its publications in four languages which is not economically viable. If we do that, it shows we are not flexible in the implementation of Government policy, We, therefore, printed it in only two languages.

    If the Member for Telok Blangah can assure us that he can get a market for a publication in any language, we will be too glad to do a translation of the publication for him.

    The Member for Serangoon Gardens raised two points, first, the role of CCCs, MCs and RCs and, secondly, the logo. I hope the

Column: 807

two questions are not inter-related. To a certain extent this seems to reflect the feeling of some CCC members that they have been over-shone by the RCs who seem to be very active. If this is a reflection of the feeling of CCC members, then it may have some connection with the logo. In this case we understand that the CCC wanted to put a logo on the exterior wall of the community centre, a logo as big as that of the MC. Is it a sense of insecurity that prompted them to show that they still exist and want to be recognized? Psychologically, that may be the reason why they want to put up a logo.

    We have always welcomed the CCCs, MCs or even the RCs to hold meetings in all our community centres. In fact, most of them do hold meetings in the community centres. We have also allowed many CCCs to put their logo outside the room which they occupy. After all, a logo is meant to show where you are. If you want to put up a logo as big as the MC's, then it will really create confusion. In the words of the Member for Serangoon Gardens, we will confuse the public as to who owns the building: is it the CCC or MC? The RCs will also want to have a big logo.

    We appreciate very much the efforts made by the CCC leaders, particularly in the case of Serangoon Gardens where they were the main figures in raising funds. But there are also other organizations which have contributed towards the funds. So if all the organizations which had contributed towards the funds, want to put up their own logos, then the community centre will become a mad house. We will allow the CCC to have their own signboard outside their office. After all, it is the People's Association building and we must give prominence to the community centre. Normally we do not display the name of a committee outside a community centre building. The CCC is a committee. We have to stick to the rules. Even if the RC wants to have an office, it can put up a signboard outside their office. But we will not allow signboards outside a CC building showing "Residents Committee", "Citizens' Consultative Committee" or "Management

Column: 808

Committee". The public will be very confused.

    As for the role and functions of the CCC, MC and RC, there are, in fact, similarities. All of them are supposed to serve the constituency, help solve the problems of the residents, and promote goodwill among the people. Those are the similarities. Thus, it is inevitable that there will be some overlapping.

    But let me come to the differences. The first difference is the scope of the territory covered, then the nature of the composition and the extent of their powers. The territorial scope of the CCC covers the whole constituency. The CCC comprises prominent leaders from all over the constituency. There may be a small number of members who do not reside or work in the constituency. But they are useful not only in their contribution towards funds but also in other ways. The CCC also looks after the physical environment and, in the case of rural constituencies, the CCC looks after lighting, drains or roads. Of course, in HDB areas there may be a conflict of interest with the RCs. But basically the CCCs are permitted to raise money, to have a scholarship fund or a welfare fund. They play a leading role in responding to campaigns by various Ministries and the National Day celebrations,

    The Management Committee comprises ideally prominent leaders from the catchment area of that community centre. It will be ideal if all the members of MCs come from the catchment area, because they know the area better. Of course, by tradition and past association, there are some members in the CCC who are not residents in that catchment area. They are from other constituencies. The duty of the MC is primarily to run the community centre, to make the community centre a bee-hive or a second home for the residents in that catchment area; how to organize activities - social, educational, vocational, recreational, etc. - and how to draw the residents into the community centre, have an inter-action and promote good neighbourliness among the residents. Of course, they need to know the require-

Column: 809

ments of that ares and find. the means to meet those requirements.

    The Residents Committee's scope is limited to the respective zones of HDB flats it represents. No non-residents can be a member of the RC. They must come from that zone. They must live there. The scope of the RC's duty relates to living conditions, better lifts, security, good neighbourhood and organize picnics for residents in the zone. It is connected with the quality of life of the residents there.

    I must say that until today the three organizations have worked rather harmoniously. In some areas some conflict is inevitable. I think the fundamental factor is attitude. If each organization takes an antagonistic attitude, and there is a Chinese saying, Hao da xi gong (    ) which means everyone wants to feel bigger than the other, and want to claim credit, then we can expect a lot of conflict, rivalry, friction and other problems. If one takes an attitude of comradeship, like members of a family and work as one, knowing one's boundaries and cooperate with one another, then they can be very complementary and supplementary. In this case I would suggest the formation, as has been done in some constituencies, of a steering committee in which the CCC, MC and RC will have representatives. They can thrash out their differences and discuss common problems and iron out whatever difficulties they may face. If they take this attitude, I think there should be no area of conflict and all can work very harmoniously together.
